299. Hansford, (Mrs. Percy)
WHAT DID YOU DO IN CANADA DURING WWI?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and will it)

University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon,

... (1908)

... (with oxen)

Rating Pan, Oatmeal

... (signature)

Mrs. Hamford
more or less personal, which would have no place in the object of the questionnaire.

I trust this will be of use to your department.

Sincerely Yours,

[Signature]

P. Hanford
Dear Sir,

In response to a request from the Women's Club, I have pleased the enclosed questionnaire and now await your reply.

The answers given are based almost entirely upon memory, and I believe they serve as a fair indication of feelings and hopes of a single use. However, I have endeavored to combine these views with every possible care to express them in the form of a history, relative to incidents...
Dear Sir,

In response to a request from the Women's Club, I have replied to the enclosed questionnaire and now enclose it for your use.

The answers given are based almost entirely upon my own views as to how I believe the same views should be made known to the public at large. I have endeavored to convey the views of a large number of women who have been interested in the question of women's rights and suffrage, and some of them included in this letter, relative to women's rights.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

January 25th, 1937.
more or less personal, which would have no place in the object of the questionnaire.

I trust this will be of use to your department.

Sincerely Yours,

W. P. Vanford
were two burned out at the
front lot where no place in the
office of the Assistant

not to your department.

Sincerely Yours

P. D. Vanaploos
WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FAMILIES EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Percy Thompson
Address Malling Ave., Sask.
Birthplace Wellingdon, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1911
Where did you set up housekeeping? Malling Ave., Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Yorkton & Bakery Sts. (1902)
For how many people did you prepare meals? Seven
How far was it to your nearest store? 50 miles (next best place)
How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a month (with oxen)
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, Sugar, Salt, Tea, Lard, Coal oil, Matches, Syrup, Baking Powder, Yeast-cakes, Beans, Molasses, Dried Fruit, Rice, Potatoes, Oatmeal.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Rival, Royal Household, Sunrise
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.00
How much did you use graham flour? Small quantities only
Whole wheat flour? 50 lbs.
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 25 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00
What other grain products did you use? Rolled wheat for cereal
Cornmeal? Yes
Whole wheat? No
Farina? No
Other? Cream of Wheat
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? With an old-fashioned grain cracker
1. **PERSONAL HISTORY**

   - What year did you start school?
   - What was your first name?
   - What was your last name?
   - How many people did you have in your family?
   - How often did you visit your grandparents?
   - What stores did you usually buy from?

2. **FOOD AND OTHER GROCERIES**

   - How much did you pay for flour?
   - What was the usual price per pound of flour?
   - How much did you use flour?
   - Did you buy flour locally?
   - What other grain products did you use?
   - Did you grind your own flour?

---

**Handwritten Note:**
When I was younger, which would have been...
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 20 lb. sacks.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Crown Brand & Refiner.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 20 lb.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

Butter? Fresh at store.

Eggs? Shelled with a few feet.

That was the price of butter? $1.50.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Separated milk & grassed.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Rabbit, Moose.

How did you get fresh meat? Butchery.

How often did you get fresh meat? Seldom in summer.

How did you preserve meat? Canning and curing.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Only at first.

What kinds? Pheasants.

For how long? For years only.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Often in early years.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh & Cured.

Kinds? Whitefish, Perch.
1. For did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

2. Did you make butter? Yes.

3. Did you make cheese? Yes.

4. How often did you eat fresh meat?

5. Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood?

6. Did you use family recipes? Yes.

7. For how long? For many years.

8. What part did each play in the family diet? Each in equal shares.

9. Kindly sign. 

[Signature]

[Signature]
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? 
At what price? 
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) 
Price? 
What other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 
Could you get potatoes at the store? 
If not, where from? 
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes, Cabbage, Carrots, Onions, Turnips, Beets, Beans, Peas.
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? 
What weight? 
How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? 
What was the price of prunes?
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? 
Peas? 
Corn? 
Beans? 
Saskatoons? 
Other foods? 
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? 
To what extent? 
Did you make your own vinegar? 

*Note: The handwriting is quite faded and difficult to read.*
6. What kind of tea did you buy? (Yes/No) Yes

That kind of coffee did you buy? (Yes/No) No

What other beverages were bought? (Yes/No) No

7. VEGETABLES AND FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when purchased at the store? $1.50

If not, where from? (Yes/No) No

That year did you grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes: (Yes/No) No

Turnips: (Yes/No) No

In what quantities did you buy shatta navy beans? (Yes/No) No

How did you buy prunes? (In bulk or by the box?) (Yes/No) No

That weight? (Yes/No) No

That was the price of prunes? (Yes/No) No

That other dried fruit did you use in the earliest days? (Apples, pears, apricots, plums, etc.) (Yes/No) No

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by air-drying? (Yes/No) No

Other foods? (Yes/No) No

This year did you first preserve fruit by canning? (Yes/No) No

That year did you first preserve fruit by pickling? (Yes/No) No

That year did you first preserve food by smoking? (Yes/No) No

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? (Yes/No) No

To that extent? (Yes/No) No

Did you make your own vinegar? (Yes/No) No

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? ... Royal ...........................................

Did you make yeast for your own use? ... No ....... Using starter? ... No .......

What type of yeast did you use? [ ] Yeast [ ] Using a starter [ ]

Using hops? [ ] Yes [ ] No

How far was this water from your home? ...100 yards..............................

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) ...By A. Patrick...........

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (If not, river, stream, dugout)

Well.

How far was this water from your house? (If not, well, tank)

Was it brought to the house? (If not, well, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Roll, Wright, and made.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ashes? No.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal, Green, Sunlight.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood (Pebble).

Where did you get your fuel? At home land.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. No change.

Some coal used in later years.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Interior (Eaton cook stove) 1911.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Eaton, Minnesota.

What year was it purchased? 1911. Price? $25.00.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron, Tin.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Iron, stoneware, Ware, Wooden bowl (for better cooking).

When did you first see enamel ware? Used quite early.

Aluminum? After 1916-20.
13. **Spare**
   Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Yes... No...
   If you made your own, did you use Ave? Yes... No...
   What kind of laundry soap did you use? Regular... Special... Other...

14. **Fuel**
   What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal... Oil... Other...
   Have you used your fuel... On... Always... Sometimes...
   Mention any changes in the use of fuels that have taken place since you first started housekeeping. Give date when change took place.

Some coal used in later years.

15. **Clothing**
   Did you own flat iron? Yes... No...
   What year was it purchased? (Give date) Year...
   For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wood, copper, tin, homestead) Tin...
   What did you first use? (Give date) Earthenware...

Aluminum? About 1916-20...
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Main changes from bulk to smaller quantity wrapping:
- Teas to 25¢ tins.
- Soap from bars to cakes.
- Syrup from lots upward.
- Crackers from barrels to cartons.
- Tobacco from sacks to tins.

Waxed paper & cellulose replaces newspaper wrappers.
Cardboard replacing wooden cases. Glass wrappers more colorful.
Fresh fruits in cartons, frozen in storage lockers.
Fish filleted and cello-wrapped.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1914-15:

Jan. 18th, Breakfast:
Porridge. Bacon & fried potatoes. Bread, syrup.

Nov. 20th, Dinner:
Moosemeat. Potatoes, beans. Spotted dog pudding. Tea.

Aug. 1st, Supper:
Pudding (sometimes in pie). Potatoes or turnips. Baking for biscuits & jam. Tea.

Members occupying house:
- P. Hansford
- Mrs. P. Hansford
- E.P. Snowden
- Mrs. E.P. Snowden
- F.G. Hamlyn
- A.P. Cross
- W.B. Tatch

Adjacent homesteaders:
- Adjacent homesteaders

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Moosemeat. Potatoes, beans. Yorkshire pudding.
Christmas Pudding (Steamed in card peel)
Peanuts. Tea. Spruce Beer.

Persons present as listed above.
Ages ranging from 23 to 30 years.
(Three children in our family. Born 1915, 1918 and 1924.)

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Never, on the homestead. Given health & strength, no need to.
(Grainy reduced awaiting Army discharge in Pr. Albert 1918.)
Relating to my husband's experience, not mine.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

More widely varied diets now possible.
Refer to such amenities as -
Prepared foods,
Cereals,
Canned vegetables & fruits,
Pressure Cookers,
Pastry Mixes,
Quick freeze products.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Never relied greatly on prepared purchased foods.
These were rendered more convenient as family matured and left home. (from 1935)
Small quantities were then sufficient for our needs,
with resultant freshness, and varied diets.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Buying governed strictly by prevailing prices which were generally far less than present times.
Although earning capacities were restricted 40 years ago,
it was possible to live fairly comfortably on income from labor and farming operations.
We asked no credit buying, and during summer periods of working out on farms, counted ourselves fairly secure for winter provisions on homestead with from $50 to $80 according to extent of family. (Possible need of medical aid was discounted, as a luxury)
Small trading with belts, seneca root and horse hair supplemented the lender. Many pioneers had ice wells for summer storage, and smoke houses for curing.
Much homemade furniture was in evidence.
Quality of merchandise compared very favorably with those of present days. Perhaps not so attractively displayed but nevertheless dependable and wholesome.
Little need for government controls or subsidies.
Shortages, if any, were anticipated adequately by reason and experience, in regard to distance from buying centres.
Never relied greatly on prepared purchased foods.

There were rendered more convenient as family members and local home (Cam 1935).

Small quantities were then sufficient for our needs, with resultant freshness, and varied diets.

Canned vegetables & fruits.

Pressure Cookers

Bakery Mixes.

Quick freeze products.

21. Remember to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of canning or freezing.

Refer to such a mailing as "Better to Such a Mailings."

Prepared foods.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and storing foods in your own family planning days in central Kansas.

Ireland's Ideas lists of canned foods, recipes, and storage methods are available at the local extension office.

Buying governed strictly by prevailing prices which were generally far less than of present times.

Although earning capacities were restricted by income from labor and farming operations, shortages were not felt.

It was possible to live fairly comfortably on incomes from $800 to $1000 per year.

We also enjoyed many vacations and summer periods abroad.

For example, during the Depression years, we visited Europe several times.
Oxford

No. 613 S
